Let $f(n)$ be minimal such that $\{1,\ldots,n-1\}$ can be partitioned into $f(n)$ classes so that $n$ cannot be expressed as a sum of distinct elements from the same class. How fast does $f(n)$ grow?



Alon and Erd\H{o}s \cite{AlEr96} proved that $f(n) = n^{1/3+o(1)}$, and more precisely\[\frac{n^{1/3}}{(\log n)^{4/3}}\ll f(n) \ll \frac{n^{1/3}}{(\log n)^{1/3}}(\log\log n)^{1/3}.\]Vu \cite{Vu07} improved the lower bound to\[f(n) \gg \frac{n^{1/3}}{\log n}.\]Conlon, Fox, and Pham \cite{CFP21} determined the order of growth of $f(n)$ up to a multiplicative constant, proving\[f(n) \asymp \frac{n^{1/3}(n/\phi(n))}{(\log n)^{1/3}(\log\log n)^{2/3}}.\]




References


[AlEr96] Alon, Noga and Erd\H{o}s, Paul, Sure monochromatic subset sums. Acta Arith. (1996), 269-272.

[CFP21] Conlon, D. and Fox, J. and Pham, H. T., Subset sums, completeness and colorings. arXiv:2104.14766 (2021).

[Vu07] Vu, Van H., Some new results on subset sums. J. Number Theory (2007), 229-233.
